titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to James R. Hoffa Documentation collection, 1954-1976 LAC0005

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-18 11:50:59 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: The collection contains newspaper clippings, magazine articles, trial transcripts, publicity materials, copies of congressional hearings, photographs, videocassettes, vinyl records and audio tapes. This material covers a variety of background materials on James R. Hoffa, covering the time period from 1956, when Hoffa was Vice President of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, past his disappearance in 1975 to the election of his son, James Hoffa Jr., as General-President of the Teamsters.
did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site, and may require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical note
bioghist.p: James R. Hoffa (1913- ) was an American labor union leader and former President of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Hoffa was born in Brazil, Indiana in 1913. He left school at the age of 14 in 1927 and began full-time manual labor to help support his family. Hoffa had begun his career with the Teamsters as a union organizer in Detroit in the early 1930s, where he became president of Local 299. He was first elected Vice President in 1952 and later served as the union's General President from 1958 to 1971. He secured the first national agreement for teamsters' rates in 1964, and played a major role in the growth and development of the union, which eventually became the largest single union in the United States.

Prior to Hoffa's election, the Teamsters and his predecessor, Dave Beck, had become the focus of a congressional investigation by the Senate Select Committee on Improper Activities in the Labor or Management Field, which was chaired by Senator McClellan from Arkansas. The chief counsel of the committee was Robert F. Kennedy. The investigations against the Teamsters and Hoffa continued throughout the late 1950s and early 1960s, and Hoffa was repeatedly called to testify before the McClellan committee, which charged him with a wide range of improper and illegal activities, including use of union funds for personal purposes, corruption, and perjury. In 1964 Hoffa was convicted and began serving his sentences in federal prison in Lewisburg, Pennsylvania.

In 1971, President Nixon issued a conditional pardon for Hoffa, releasing him from prison under the condition that he remained inactive in union management. Hoffa then worked on a variety of issues, in including a campaign for prison reform, but retained a relatively low profile, while working on a comeback at the local level. On July 30, 1975, he disappeared under mysterious circumstances at the Machus Red Fox restaurant in a Detroit suburb. He married Josephine Poszywak in 1936. The couple had two children: a daughter, Barbara Ann, and a son, James.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The provenance of the collection is not entirely clear. The materials came to the LHRC in two boxes, which were labeled "JRH Personnel." and most likely originated from different departments at the IBT headquarters, possibly from the library, the public relations and press office, the General President's office, and the legal department.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains newspaper clippings, magazine articles, trial transcripts, publicity materials, and copies of congressional hearings. This material covers a variety of background materials on James R. Hoffa, covering the time period from 1956, when Hoffa was Vice President of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, until his disappearance in 1975. it also includes documents for the James R. Hoffa Memorial Scholarship fund from 2008-2011.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into 10 series: Media, Addresses and speeches, IBT press releases, IBT publicity materials, Transcript of Joint Council meeting, Congressional hearings and investigations, Trial documentation, Subject files, Re-printed and photocopied materials, and Unpublished materials.

controlaccess.subject: Labor
Labor unions
Labor unions -- United States -- History -- 20th century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains media coverage of James R. Hoffa and his work with the IBT, as well as coverage of the investigations and following trials against him. Included in the series are newspaper clippings, magazine and journal articles, transcripts from TV and radio shows, audio cassettes, Vinyl records, VHS tapes, and wire reports. The materials, which are arranged chronologically, are covering the time period from 1956 until 1975, and include shorter notices, as well as extensive background analyses and journalistic investigations. The media coverage is on a range of issues including his ascent to the Presidency of the IBT, the exclusion of the IBT from the AFL-CIO after his election as President, the investigations of JRH and the Teamsters by the McClellan commission, spearheaded by its counsel, Robert F. Kennedy, the initiative for a National Master Freight Agreement, the trials against JRH in Nashville, Chattanooga, and Chicago, his imprisonment in 1967, Richard's Nixon's parole for Hoffa before Christmas, 1971, Hoffa's campaign for prison reform, and finally his mysterious disappearance in 1975. It also includes pieces on Hoffa's positions on a variety of labor and economic issues at the time, including collective bargaining, unemployment, automation, and income tax reform. In addition, it includes some media reports focusing more generally on organizing drives and political initiatives of the IBT.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Documents in this subseries have been aranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The contents of this subseries are made up of newspaper articles pertaining to James R. Hoffa and Roy Lee Williams term as Teamstrs chief. Contents are dated between 1934-2005.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains addresses and speeches at area conferences of the Teamsters, most of which were given by James R. Hoffa. This series covers the time period from 1954 until 1962.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains press releases from the Teamsters News Service, and from the Drive News Service from 1962 until 1965, many of which deal with James R. Hoffa, and the investigations and trials against him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains publicity materials about JRH issued by the IBT: two profiles, titled "The Name is Hoffa," the first published in 1956, and the second one Circa 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "The Name is Hoffa," IBT, Joint Council Number 13, 1956

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the original transcript from a Joint Council meeting in support of James R. Hoffa in March 1967, including remarks by James R. Hoffa with handwritten notes. The transcript is not entirely in order and appears to be missing some pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an original transcript from a Joint Council meeting in support of James R. Hoffa in March 1967, including remarks by James R. Hoffa with handwritten notes. The transcript is not entirely in order and appears to be missing some pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains documentation on Congressional hearings and investigations regarding JRH from 1961 until 1967, including copies from the Congressional Record, a complete transcript of hearings of a subcommittee on investigations on "Racket Control of New York City Teamster Locals" from 1961, a statement by JRH on the right to collective bargaining before the Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries and his testimony on the National Highway Safety Act (1966).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hearings, Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations of the Office of Government Operations, United States Senate, "Racket Control of New York City Teamster Locals," vol. 5, Washington, DC, January 25, 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains documentation on trials of James R. Hoffa, including the trials in Nashville, TN, and in Chattanooga (1962-1964), as well as his trial in Chicago (1964). It includes transcripts of proceedings, testimonies, exhibits, and correspondence regarding trials and subsequent appeals up to the Supreme Court.
